Caronte Labs Boilerplate aaaa

1. introduction

Build modern, lightweight, semantic websites

A low level, unobtrusive boilerplate that provides a minimal development environment for getting started front-end project fast. It also includes some optional SASS helpers and resources to create elegant websites fastly. Built at Caronte Labs

Summary

  • 1. Introduction
  • 2. Gettin Started
  • 3. Managing Assets
  • 4. Managing Assets
  • 5. Mixins
    • Typography
    • Palettes
    • Shadows
    • Buttons
  • 6. License

2. Gettin Started

Live deveolpment for fast prototyping.

Gulp and Grunt are avoided in favour of minimal scripting written using native node.js API and a few of third party modules.

Be sure to have node.js and npm installed on your machine, then it's very simple to get started.

1. Install dependencies

npm install

2. Start development server

node labs --server

You are ready to go

Visit http://localhost:3000 and start editing content of the src/ folder. Everything is reloaded live

Full API

Options

A list of available options:

--help

node labs --help

Display all available options

--server

node labs --server

Start development server

--server --silent

node labs --server --silent

Prevent server to emit sounds

--production

node labs --production

Build production version

About IDE

The IDE simply watches files you edit during development and build* the distribuition version. It starts a web server to serve the distribuition version and inject a javascript script in all html pages to establish a persistent connection with the live server and allows to reload them once any of the file in the src/ folder changes.

*During the build process CSS files are compiled (using SASS), assets are included in html files, SHA checksum is calculated for each asset, and files and assets are moved from src/ folder to dist/ folder. Nothing more, nothing less

External Modules

Gulp, Grunt or other task auotomator are avoided in favour of minimal node.js native functions and a few of well tested, popular modules. These are:

  • Async (async utilities)
  • Yargs (parameters passing)
  • Express.js (web server framework)
  • Socket.io (persistent connection for live development)
  • Colors (better looking logging)
  • Play (audio utility)

Note all these modules aren't really exploited. We plan to remove them in next versions. Feel free to contribute.

1. Typography

Default

I am an <h2> element

I am an <h3> element

@include typography("global");

Passing global as parameters, default styling for all descendent <h1>, <h2>, <h3>, <h4>, <p> and <blockquote> tags are applied. Alternatively you can restrict styles to a certain element, for example you can use:
@include typography("h1") to set <h1> target style for that element.

"Caronte non ti crucciar..." (Dante)

This scale is derived from Robert Bringhurst's principles, as documented here

Magazine

I am an <h2> element

I am an <h3> element

@include typography("global", "magazine");

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Nunc nec lorem vel lacus pretium fringilla vitae ut tortor. Donec facilisis tellus eget dolor sagittis, sit amet interdum ante imperdiet. Praesent massa nisl, maximus semper cursus sit amet, interdum nec nunc.

Palettes

Inspiration for your web project

Palettes are collected from many sources and submitted by users at all: canova.caronte.co/palettes

This boilerplate includes a large sets of palettes to get you inspired and getting start fast:

.class {background: palette(palettename, colorindex);}

Example:

.class {background: palette("red-white", 7);}

green-light-blue

blue-light-green

yellow-green-blue

yellow-green

green-blue-rose

blue-rose

red-white

black

green-white

purple-white

orange-white

red-yellow

Shadows

Box Shadow with custom color and verbosity: @include card(1, white)

@include card(0)
@include card(1)
@include card(2)
@include card(3)
@include card(4)
@include card(5)
